questions.question: The Physical Layer is the foundation on which other layers build.
Guided Transmission Media includes wireless transmission.
Communication Satellites are part of the Physical Layer.
Digital Modulation and Multiplexing are core components related to the Physical Layer.
The Mobile Telephone System operates independently of the Physical Layer.
Properties of wires, fiber, and wireless propagation are discussed at the Physical Layer.
The key problem in sending digital bits is utilizing analog signals to represent discrete values.
Modulation is the process of sending analog signals using digital bits.
Guided transmission media includes physical conduits like wires and fiber optics.
All transmission media share the same physical properties and performance metrics.
Twisted pairs, coaxial cable, and power lines are examples of guided transmission media.
Fiber optic cables are considered a type of guided transmission media.
Sending data physically on media like tapes or disks can provide a very high bandwidth link but poor latency.
The throughput of physically transporting storage media (like 1000 800GB tapes) is generally slower than modern long-distance networks.
The propagation delay or message delay when physically sending tapes is very high.
Twists in twisted pair wires are designed to increase radiated signal and interference.
Category 5 Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP) cable typically contains four pairs of wires.
A full-duplex link is used for simultaneous transmission in both directions.
A half-duplex link allows transmission in both directions at the same time.
A simplex link supports transmission in both directions.
Twisted pair cables generally have better shielding and more bandwidth for longer distances than fiber cables.
Fiber optic cables transmit light through very long, thin strands of glass.
Fiber-to-the-Home (FTTH) is a common implementation for high-speed fiber cables.
Fiber optic cables utilize total internal reflection to keep light trapped within the core.
Light-emitting diodes (LEDs) and lasers are the primary light sources used in fiber optic transmission.
Single-mode fiber features a core narrow enough (approx. 10 microns) that light propagates in a single path.
Single-mode fiber is typically paired with LEDs for long-distance transmissions.
Multi-mode fiber typically has a larger core (approx. 50 microns) allowing light to bounce in multiple paths.
Multi-mode fiber is commonly used with lasers for high-speed, long-distance backbone links.
The electromagnetic spectrum used for networking includes radio wave transmission.
Microwave transmission is part of the electromagnetic spectrum used in wireless communications.
Wireless transmission characteristics are identical to those of wired or fiber transmission.
Radio waves in the High Frequency (HF) band have the ability to bounce off the ionosphere.
VLF, LF, and MF radio bands have the characteristic of following the curvature of the earth.
Microwave transmission is the primary medium used for modern WiFi and 3G/4G networks.
Infrared and light transmission are the preferred choices for wide-area broadcast systems.
Wireless signal strength can be significantly attenuated or reflected by everyday physical objects.
Multipath fading describes variations in signal strength caused by mobility and signal reflection.
Point-to-point light transmission can be used for network links without using fiber optic cable.
Light transmission is highly directional and provides substantial bandwidth.
Wireless networks are generally easier and less expensive to deploy than physical cable infrastructure.
Wireless networks naturally support device mobility.
Wireless transmissions are immune to interference from other simultaneous transmitters.
Signal strength in wireless environments varies greatly based on distance and obstacles.
Wired networks easily support mobile users moving between locations.
Wireless networks naturally support broadcast, allowing one transmitter to reach multiple receivers.
Wired networks are easier to engineer for a fixed, reliable data rate over point-to-point links.
Satellites are effective for broadcast distribution and establishing connectivity in remote areas.
Geostationary (GEO) satellites are the only type of satellite used for data communications.
Low-Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites are frequently used for low-latency communication systems.
Communication satellites vary in properties such as latency and coverage based on their altitude.
GEO satellites are placed in orbit approximately 35,000 km above a fixed location on the equator.
VSAT (Very Small Aperture Terminal) systems typically require a hub station for communication.
Low-Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites are located at higher altitudes than GEO satellites.
Iridium-style satellite systems utilize a constellation of LEO satellites to provide global coverage.
Satellite communications are susceptible to bandwidth limitations and interference that must be managed.
Fiber optic technology can be instantly deployed anywhere without existing physical infrastructure.
Frequency Division Multiplexing (FDM) divides a channel by assigning users to different frequency bands.
In FDM, all users transmit on the same frequency but at different, alternating times.
Frequency Division Multiplexing assigns overlapping frequency ranges to each user to maximize space.
In FDM systems, a multiplexor is used to combine multiple input signals for a single high-speed line.
A demultiplexor is used at the receiving end to separate multiplexed frequency signals.
Frequency Division Multiplexing is one of the oldest multiplexing techniques used in radio and television.
Frequency Division Multiplexing is entirely immune to external electronic noise.
Time Division Multiplexing (TDM) shares a medium by dividing the available transmission time into slots.
Synchronous Time Division Multiplexing allocates an equal and fixed amount of time to every connected device.
Statistical Time Division Multiplexing allocates time slots dynamically, only when a device has data to send.
Synchronous TDM allocates time slices even if a specific device has no data to transmit, which can be inefficient.
Space is wasted in the multiplexed stream of a statistical multiplexor if a workstation is inactive.
Statistical Time Division Multiplexing frames often include addresses to identify the source of each data group.
Wavelength Division Multiplexing (WDM) is a multiplexing technique designed for copper-based networks.
Wavelength Division Multiplexing allows multiple data streams using different 'colors' of light to share one fiber.
Discrete Multitone (DMT) is a multiplexing technique commonly found in DSL systems.
In DMT, subchannels are modulated using Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (QAM).
Code Division Multiplexing (CDM/CDMA) allows multiple devices to transmit on the same frequency at the same time using unique codes.
In CDMA, the spreading codes used for data transmission must be independent of the data itself.
The receiver must know the unique spreading code to decipher the transmitted data in a CDMA system.
In CDMA, a mobile device typically transmits its unique code to represent a binary 1.
In CDMA, a mobile device transmits the inverse of its code to represent a binary 0.
In CDMA, to send 'nothing' (no data), a mobile device transmits a continuous stream of binary ones.
A CDMA receiver decodes a signal by multiplying the summed input by the target device's unique code.
In CDMA decoding, if the mathematical sum is near its maximum positive value, the receiver interprets the bit as a binary 1.
Compression is a Physical Layer technique used to reduce the size of data for faster transmission.
Squeezing more data over a communications line via compression results in a reduction of total transfer time.
